comments.commentBody:
"From a childhood of not doing a lot of work (cooking, laundry etc.) they are all of a sudden doing everything."

This is a very interesting observation. Children do not seem to be learning the "mechanics" of running a house. I remember being surprised several years ago when I asked students in one of my classes what they did at home, expecting "cut the grass," "fold clothes," "fix lunch on Saturday." As I recall only one or two had chores. Do they still babysit? Are parents with no prior experience in running a household in the unenviable position of trying to do it all for their kids, who will then replicate that model?

It is all about a lack of political will and/or power to reallocate resources for a healthy and sustainable society. And we have seen this story before.

During the Cold War, we engaged in a preposterous arms race, investing vast amounts of national treasure and human resources to build a stockpile of massive weapons that, by definition, really had no use.

Today, it is all about a wealth race. Which nation can mint the most billionaires?

But unlike in the arms race, these massive relics of economic warfare will up and leave if they do not get what they want. And make no mistake, they already do to large extent: offshore accounts and outsourced labor are just two ways our Persons of Massive Wealth (PMW's) demonstrate, they are not really national assets. They are free individuals, with great power, and no national loyalty the second it would cost them a cent of their fortunes.

At least during the Cold War, we did not create autonomous ICBM's that would move to other countries if they were not perpetually succored politically. But in the wealth race, that is what we have unleashed. An army of uncontrollable wealth-seeking missiles, with no loyalty.

RiA, I thought it was horrific too.

Then I looked at the last 4 letters of the entry at 20A, and I looked at the last 4 letters of the clue for 20A.

And I told myself, there's something happening here that I am not allowed to write about in Comments!

It's unsurprising to have Mr. Summers, one of the architect of the disaster, advocating one of his working techniques, bubbles.

The permanent deficits in the leading countries of the West are caused by the plutocracy, the same exact phenomenon happened in Rome, until Italy became an empty shell, and for the same exact (political) reasons.

Plus you can't have an economy when the.1% owns or controls not just the country and its political process, but the world. Serfs stagante in all ways, and so does the socio-economy with them.

To the usual plutotocratic apocalypse, that happens every few centuries, is grafted an unprecedented ecological crisis. So this is a Greater Depression. Details in:
http://patriceayme.wordpress.com/2011/07/23/greater-depression/

Growing up, the rule my three girls had at the grocery store was "Read the ingredients. If you can pronounce all of the ingredients and you know what they look like, then we can buy that."

That eliminated Lunchables but allowed chocolate peanut butter, much to my chagrin. The girls decided on their own to bring lunch from home rather than eat school lunch, and dinners were always made from scratch and eaten at the table. "Kid food" never existed in our house!

I now have two girls in college, where they continue to eat the foods they were brought up on--ethnic dishes (Indian, Mexican, Thai, Mediterranean, Japanese and sometimes American) using whole grains, fruits and vegetables, expeller pressed oils, 100% juice, beans, tofu, fish, organic, free-range poultry, etc. When we periodically eat "junk" food, we always realize that it looks so much better than it tastes. :)

You can change that reality. I can fill up a 6'4" college student and his equally big brother (my daughter's friends) with ONE whole wheat pancake made with soy milk. (I make pan-sized pancakes...) Each pancake has about 400 calories and 17g of protein.

I'm a third-generation health-food eater. Because I grew up with home cooked, healthy food, that's what I like now and feed my family. People who grow up with potato chips and pizza like potato chips and pizza when they are adults. My husband grew up Jewish in Brooklyn. He eats what I feed him and enjoys good food, but left to his own devices, I know that he would regress to pastrami sandwiches on white rye bread in a millisecond!

Children now who eat "kid food"? They are going to be eating chicken fingers and macaroni and cheese when they are 30.

Benito, I'm not sure you understood my point. If you don't treat a spouse at least as well as a best friend, what does that say about the quality of the relationship?

Clearly, marriage requires sexual compatibility, including compatible libidos, and a meeting of the minds when it comes to values - including kids, education, money handling, and so on.

But at the core, if you aren't truly friends - sex, kids, commitments, extended family - those may keep you legally together, but you don't have much of a marriage without mutual respect and genuine liking.

Beautiful story...so appreciate being with my father in law and best friend in their last days.  My friend would ask..where am I going?  We would shake our heads together..why so soon?? But, I said, please come for me..help me when it's my time. She agreed.  Such a mystery...death...these stories help us be present for each other at the really important times.

Oh - there might be a small problem?

Uhhhm - some of these Catalans said they weren't learing from American economists - They said they were learning from -(of all people) teh damn Germans...
-(you know concerning the "sustainability thing")

Now I understand that could be a problem?
But is it that bad to be "right"?
This also includes massive subsidies for Big Agriculture, pushing garbage like HFCS and sodium into the food supply instead of healthy whole foods.

"Peoplecare" for a diverse population of 300 million people spread over 3.8 million square miles is not a trivial undertaking.

Throw in a rugged individualism and a prickly response to any and all infringement of rights and "choice", and it becomes that much more difficult.

A one-sized-fits-all solution should always be questioned when it's proposed as a cure for what ails all Americans. And after the near-collapse of our banking system, even with plenty of regulation and oversight, and the inability of this president to actually deliver a working computer system, we should be even more skeptical of solutions that are hailed as the "answer".

Richard - you state "France and the Southren Europeans stand at the edge of a precipice finantualy and socially".  Are you suggesting this is because of how their healthcare is financed and/or delivered - or perhaps something else all together.  No one is suggesting we emulate the Europeans re their past war involvement ... on the other hand WE have been continuously at war with someone somewhere on the globe since WWII.  Seems like we are emulating those nasty old Europeans without even thinking about it - sadly emulating them regarding war-making, not healthcare making or financing.  We are exceptional all right.

For Janice Badger Nelson - as an epidemiologist I make a distinction between medical care and health care. The US does not take care of the health of its people. This includes the problems of maldistribution of income and the fact that too many Americans cannot afford to feed themselves and their children adequately.

Bitcoin is a poor choice for transactions people wish to make anonymously, and most criminals realize this. It consists of a permanent, indelible record of every transaction that has ever happened with it. Yes, coins moves between account numbers rather than names, but law enforcement has shown itself to be increasingly able to trace these funds.
Compare the $200 million that went through Silk Road with the more than $6 billion that went through Liberty Reserve -- a private virtual currency specifically designed for crooks to launder money. (and even that got shut down…)

Thank you sir. And allow me to exercise my right of free expression to say I'm glad you were not carried off to Oz by a tornado.

But wasn't it George Mason who first proposed the free speech/free press guarantees?

Rima, in this case your comments are even better than Mr. Krugman's column!

As to the stench from Geithner's new gig, I'm wearing my gas mask as I read.

After Clinton, Geithner, Summers and Rubin etc, dismantled our financial regulation sufficiently, sending jobs off shore increased. And with the excess profits from that, corporations could easily hire more DC lobbyists, who increased by the thousands to influence lawmaking.

These laws led to more tax breaks for business, and more sending jobs out of the country. Leading to further excessive profits to donate to the campaigns of right wing congresspeople. An virtuous cycle for the 1 percent, a vicious cycle for the 99.

And voila we have the world's most dysfunctional democracy. With a downward living standard for all. With govt shutdowns to keep 40 million American unfortunates uninsured against the devastation of serious illness.

What a coup for the world's most superior country. And now Lawrence Summer tells us, we should all just get used to it. Krugman can't seem to fund much argument in rebuttal.

Why are we pretending to be a super power that can control events around the world when we seem not to have the resources at least according to Republicans to help our people at home.  But we do seem to find the resources  for financial schemes by big investors which produce nothing for the little guy but huge land falls for stock holders that creates nothing, but a few new yachts..  60 minutes tonight featured a group of rich people  who have pledged to turn back one half their money back to charities, but listening to them it seemed that little of this money would go to creating new well paying jobs or repairing infrastructure.  Their hearts seem to be in the right place, but only government can provide stimulus that might lift the entire economy..  Trickle down after all is only a trickle.  If we were truly interested in helping people  rebuild their lives we could do it, but it would require lifting our sights from temporary profits and military adventurism to providing infrastructure, education, solid health care, feeding our people and encouraging research and development in both the government and corporate sectors.  If we believe that starving ourselves through austerity is what we need then starvation is all that we will have.

In the article "Poverty in America is Mainstream" (N.Y. Times 11.04.13) we learn our nation provides less support than other industrialized nations. If our economy is going to often be somewhat depressed, it is imperative our government change its attitude toward those who are suffering the most. Companies that pay little taxes, farm bill support going to millionaires, etc. cannot be tolerated while we give little help and encouragement to those most affected by a depressed economy. "What about the generous assistance we provide to the poor? Contrary to political rhetoric, the American social safety net is extremely weak and filled with gaping holes. Furthermore, it has become even weaker over the past 40 years because of various welfare reform and budget cutting measures. We currently expend among the fewest resources within the industrialized countries in terms of pulling families out of poverty and protecting them from falling into it. And the United States is one of the few developed nations that does not provide universal health care, affordable child care, or reasonably priced low-income housing. As a result, our poverty rate is approximately twice the European average."
Privatize Social Security so that Wall Street can steal it all?  No thanks.
There is a reason why we call the government retirement program Social “Security.” Relying on the ups and downs of the stock market is a bad idea.

You should remember four words before you dive into those "opportunities" or advocate that anyone should follow you into the pool: Long-Term Capital Management.

http://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-birth-of-wall-streets-bailout-culture

Your suggestion that Social Security should maybe be privatized would put people of the same mindset as the founders of LTCM between you and your government guarantee of an independent future. Personally, I don't think that's such a good idea. When that bubble bursts, what's left?

The decline in the cost of transporting both finished goods and raw materials, ready availability of cheap foreign labor, notably in China, and the increasing displacement of workers by technology have placed a lid on most wages and salaries world-wide.  Not only blue collar factory employees, but lawyers, engineers, government workers and even non-specialized medical doctors have seen their earned income stagnate as formerly discrete regional and national markets integrate into one global economy.  Professor Krugman and "The Times'" editorial board would print money, steeply increase marginal tax rates and attach wealth to stimulate the economy and reduce income inequality.  Rather than more market-distorting intervention and coercion by government agencies, a better remedy would be to privatize substantially Social Security.  Doing so would give all working Americans the opportunity to benefit from the historic economic pendulum swing away from labor towards capital.

In the history of this column, there hasn't been one economic policy proposal offered by this author, or Larry Summers, that has actually worked in any way close to what they predicted.

Our return on the taxpayer investments in these policies have been abysmal.

And like degenerate gamblers, their only additional advise, in the face of these disasters realized, is to double down on these extremely bad bets they call economic policy.

Time and time again.

Are we witnessing the effects of a new generation being less well-educated than the preceding one? First time in American history.

I read that the educational level of lots of Latinos is not improving, mired in poverty, broken families, high fertility rates.

In fact, I can't help but wonder if the downward pressure on wages is the ultimate result of broken and unstable families among all races, and the main contributor to keeping earnings and demand down in the United States.

Economics is the study of incentives so there should be more clarity around present conditions.

CEOs are paid ever higher compensation to cut worker salaries, benefits and increase productivity by reducing labor unit costs.

The 1960 minimum wage would be $33 hour in real dollars today, so the modern CEO has managed to compress real wage growth, cut real benefits and pensions, and automate successfully.

Corporate profits and margins are at record levels and wealth inequality is at levels not seen since before the Depression.

Henry Ford understood he had to pay his workers enough to be able to afford to buy his cars. Modern CEOs believe in the economic game theory that they can cut their own worker's compensation while workers at competitors remain steady and their ready consumer.

Sorry, turns out capitalism is a bit of a Ponzi scheme. Everyone out for themselves ends up with wealth at the top of the pyramid. Without a mechanism for fair redistribution there is no sufficient consumer demand for goods and thus excess unemployment.

Only government can square the deal for the betterment of capitalists and workers alike. The government can enforce incentives to hire through tax policy and more, ultimately supporting demand.

Until we stop giving tax breaks for accounting fictions that live in tax havens and start giving tax breaks for job creation we are doomed to live with tepid economic growth and relatively high unemployment.

"an economy whose normal condition is one of inadequate demand"

This began when middle class income stopped getting its share of growth. The bubbles sustained us for a time as the middle class sank into debt. Then the bubbles burst, and the middle class was suddenly broke.

The middle class can't come back, because the income of the country has been taken in unheard of percentages by a few wealthy who don't spend it the way the middle class would, and did.

We are in depression because the wealthy Bogarted so much of the income. and as they accumulated that the assets too, of the country for the last thirty years that they broke the economy, permanently crippling demand.

What will break if greed goes too far? Here we see.

It is quite interesting that you note the expanding of debt from 1985 on when St. Reagan was in power. It is during his reign that we have the dismantling of the War on Poverty and the sanctioning of union busting tactics: from Reagan's dismantling of the air traffic controllers to Lorenzo's bankrupting of Continental Airlines. While all that was going on, the deregulation disease was becoming a contagion and income disparity began growing at an exponential rate.

Larry Summers held a major part in creating the economic climate we live in by charging to destroy the Glass-Steagall Act thus creating a self-fulfilling prophecy for his boom-blah economic cycle. If we put Glass-Steagall back in place, regulate the derivatives market and tax it like stock market, we can avoid bubbles, and perhaps put investment back into real investment instead of schemes to bet cheap, borrowed money on financial legerdemain.

First, I disagree that a slowing rate of population growth should necessarily mean economic doldrums. Rather it requires a restructuring of our economy that actually should raise the quality of life for all of us. Startling increases in productivity means a leaner workforce is required today to produce the same wealth as before. Although today's higher efficiencies translates into less employment in today's paradigm, it could also translate into a shorter work week. It could translate into better health care for everyone. It could translate into better education for everyone.

We have not become so enlightened. We continue to experience future shock; our technological advances are leveraged by our financial sector for their greatest good; not our greatest good.

The world has never created so much wealth as it does today. This day.

"The effects of a perpetual stimulus to create artificial demand would peter out as soon as the dollar was worth nothing and our debt-service grew unmanageable in a perpetually slumping economy..."

If the dollar loses value our exports become more competitive. Imports become more expensive; domestically made products are more competitive.

It's expansionary.

Yes, oil imports cost more. So, alternative energy sources become more competitive.

And yes, that shopping spree in Paris will cost more, so the wealthy will squeal and kvetch.

You got a problem with any of this?

Mr. Brown, the Party of No (the GOP and 1%-ers) may come around to your thinking once they wise up and figure out that if the underclass has no money, then they won't have anyone to sell their goods to. Business really NEEDS those 47% walking around with money in their pocket so they can buy the millions of products they show us each day in the noisy, pounding gotta-have-it TV commercials.

In the 1970's the Party of No finally caved in and started giving women credit cards, car loans, and home loans once they figured out WOW, that was a 50% increase in potential buyers for their goods!!! Yippee!!!

Now the Party of No is trying to romance gays, blacks and (God Forbid!!!) the brighter, smarter legislators are even (shudder, shudder) thinking of getting off their duffs and stop obfuscating on every sane solution regarding immigration reform...

Unfortunately, the very folks who need to read this and adjust their monetary agendas for America are watching Fox News and Duck Dynasty, and reading any newspaper but The NY Times... Ahem.

So the problem with the unemployed and the underemployed is that they don't spend enough?

Just so! They don't spend enough on themselves to improve their individual lives and they don't spend enough in the aggregate to grow the economy.

As productivity has increased profits, the working population has become underfunded relative to the level of demand needed for a healthy economy.

The solution is to fund the underfunded.

Infrastructure, public safety, subsidies for food, healthcare, housing, transportation, early childhood education, training and higher education all provide long term benefits, but also create immediate demand.

Why does the investor class not salivate at the prospect?
